description.value: Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) figure of a nude male, fragment.  Standing nude youth; preserved from the neck to the knees; right elbow and hand are damaged. He is standing in a frontal position with the left leg slightly advanced with the weight evenly distributed. The shoulders are very broad, rounded and sloping; the torso is tubular though expanding around the chest. The pectorals are rendered separately with a fine incised line to indicate them. The right arm is angled, the closed right hand is placed on the chest below the pectorals; the thumb is stretched out, the hand is not holding any object. The left arm is hanging down the left side, below the pectoral it is separated from the torso for a short bit. The left hand is clenched and it has been suggested that it is holding a 'shadow rod' (Schattenstab); the thumb is stretched downwards. The crook of the arm is indicated by a dent; the upper arms are club-like, the lower arms thin. Underbelly and pubes are slightly protruding, the navel is concave; the waist is not indicated. The back is straight and flat with a small round buttocks; the spine is indicated by a thin line. A certain degree of curvature is indicating the muscles of the upper legs in the front. The hair is to be reconstructed as wig-like falling down to the neck as a thick mass; it's lower edge is rendered as five short, broad and pointed spikes with the outermost being cut in half.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

The hair is to be reconstructed as wig-like falling down to the neck as a thick mass; it's lower edge is rendered as five short, broad and pointed spikes with the outermost being cut in half.

description.value: Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) figure of a nude male, fragment.  Standing nude youth; preserved from the neck to the knees; right elbow and hand are damaged. He is standing in a frontal position with the left leg slightly advanced with the weight evenly distributed. The shoulders are very broad, rounded and sloping; the torso is tubular though expanding around the chest. The pectorals are rendered separately with a fine incised line to indicate them. The right arm is angled, the closed right hand is placed on the chest below the pectorals; the thumb is stretched out, the hand is not holding any object. The left arm is hanging down the left side, below the pectoral it is separated from the torso for a short bit. The left hand is clenched and it has been suggested that it is holding a 'shadow rod' (Schattenstab); the thumb is stretched downwards. The crook of the arm is indicated by a dent; the upper arms are club-like, the lower arms thin. Underbelly and pubes are slightly protruding, the navel is concave; the waist is not indicated. The back is straight and flat with a small round buttocks; the spine is indicated by a thin line. A certain degree of curvature is indicating the muscles of the upper legs in the front. The hair is to be reconstructed as wig-like falling down to the neck as a thick mass; it's lower edge is rendered as five short, broad and pointed spikes with the outermost being cut in half.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) figure of a male, fragment.  Standing nude youth; preserved from the neck to the knees; the surface shows white-greyish coloured areas. On the left pectoral and upper arms there are fine fissures and holes, possibly resulting from a fire; the left upper leg shows horizontal grating marks, the inside vertical marks. No traces of colour remain, only a red shimmer in the navel.  The figure is in a frontal position with the left leg advanced and the right sharply drawn back, the weight is shifted entirely to the right leg.  The high slender figure is leaning slightly towards the right side of the body. The very broad shoulders are rounded and slightly declining. The right arm is angled with the clenched hand resting against the chest below the pectorals; the hand is empty. The left arm is hanging down at the side and is slightly drawn in towards the torso; the left lower arm and the clenched hand rest against the upper leg. The thumb is stretched downwards and it has been argued that the hand is holding a 'shadow-rod' (Schattenstab). The slender torso is drawn in around the waist; the flat chest broadens towards the upper arms. The pectorals are reaching fairly far down and their lower edges are indicated by two light semicircular grooves. Small incised circles indicate the nipples which are protruding slightly; the navel is concave. Underbelly and pubes are slightly protruding. The back is almost entirely flat, the spine is indicated as an uneven groove. The musculature of upper arms, upper legs and buttocks is indicated by flatly swelling and retreating curvature. The hair is to be reconstructed in a wig-like fashion, falling down the back as an even mass with a horizontal edge while the strand of hair on either side in the front ends in three short pointy spikes with the outermost cut in half.

description.value: Black granite kneeling naophorous male figure wearing the bag-wig; shrine contains Osiris; incised Hieroglyphic text on the back-pillar, sides of the shrine and round the plinth; upper body repaired.

description.value: Black granite naophorous figure of the kneeling male official Hornebkhaset on a slim rectangular base.  The figure is depicted in a kneeling position and resting on his heels, while he supports a small naos shrine in his lap. The shrine contains the image of the funerary god Osiris, identifiable through his mummified form, feathered atef-crown, and the crook and flail implements held in his hands. Hornebkhaset wears a knee-length kilt which is belted at the waist and a smooth shoulder-length ‘bag wig’, a simple headcloth style typical of the 26th Dynasty. The chest is bare, with subtle modelling of the musculature of the upper body. The stone fill between the arms and torso is intact, often deliberately left to ensure the integrity of the stone sculpture. The face is rounded and fleshy, with wide almond shaped eyes and a slim nose. The mouth is small with the outer corners slightly upturned to suggest a small smile. The naos shrine contains a hieroglyphic inscription on either side of … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Black granite naophorous figure of the kneeling male official Hornebkhaset on a slim rectangular base.  The figure is depicted in a kneeling position and resting on his heels, while he supports a small naos shrine in his lap. The shrine contains the image of the funerary god Osiris, identifiable through his mummified form, feathered atef-crown, and the crook and flail implements held in his hands. Hornebkhaset wears a knee-length kilt which is belted at the waist and a smooth shoulder-length ‘bag wig’, a simple headcloth style typical of the 26th Dynasty. The chest is bare, with subtle modelling of the musculature of the upper body. The stone fill between the arms and torso is intact, often deliberately left to ensure the integrity of the stone sculpture. The face is rounded and fleshy, with wide almond shaped eyes and a slim nose. The mouth is small with the outer corners slightly upturned to suggest a small smile. The naos shrine contains a hieroglyphic inscription on either side of … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) male figure, fragment, burnt.  Standing youth; preserved from neck to thigh; the head is missing, so are the left leg from the thigh and the right leg from below the knee.  The figure stands to the front, the weight on both legs, the left slightly advanced. The youth is wearing a chiton and a himation; the sleeves of the chiton are indicated by horizontal grooves on the upper arms (not to be misread as armlets), its edge is visible around the neck. The himation is slung around the left shoulder, the edges are indicated by diagonal incised lines across the chest and and back. Other than that the body appears to be in the nude; the horizontal line of the himation's lower edge is not indicated though the oblique incision above the pubes might be its upper edge. The chest is protruding and separated by a line in the centre. Three angular tresses are falling down in the front over chest and upper arms on either side. Nine broad and flat tresses are falling down the back with the outermost left one being centrally grooved; their lower edge is only slightly arched and the edges rounded. On the sides of the neck the tresses are separated by a tapered cut. Down to the hips the arms are mostly separated from the body. The back is worked; the spinal groove is on the left side.

description.value: Fragment of gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) naked male figure.  Standing nude youth. preserved from neck to knees; head and lower legs missing and the right arm is much eroded. He is standing in a frontal position, the weight equally put on both legs, the left slightly advanced, the right drawn back. The arms are at the sides, slightly separated, the elbows are a little bent, the hands closed; the elbow is set low. The hands are worn and it cannot be said whether they are holding rods or not.  The hair falls in five tresses on either side in front of the shoulders while eight tresses are shown on the back which are equally long and only lightly rippled.. The shoulders are narrow and sloping, the waist long and incurved. The breast is a protruding mass without division, or pectoral line. The back has no spinal groove; the buttocks is very small. The abdomen is sunken.

description.value: Light grey limestone figure of a youth with lion, painted.  Nude youth standing on a rectangular, slightly convex plinth holding a lion before him, head downwards. Repaired across the thighs and knees. The right arm is broken away from the shoulder; the right edge of the plinth is missing. The surface seems washed-out. Traces of black paint on the hair, of red on the corners of the mouth; a red headband is painted right below the forelock, a red band at the base of the neck. Traces of black and yellow paint on the lion's body, of yellow on the ears.  The figure's hair is a flat surface, parted in the centre and falling on the back with a straight edge. The features are worn; the face oval, the eyes slightly oblique, the mouth indicating a smile with the corners turned downwards. The earlobes are particularly large. The body is schematised with wide sloping shoulders and a slim waist. The arm is sturdy and mostly separated from the body. There are no indications of musculature or bone structure on the upper body. The base of the neck is sharp-edged and emphasised by the red band. The feet are almost parallel with the left slightly advanced; between the feet the stone has not been entirely removed. The upper half of the back is fairly flat; legs and buttocks are shown in the round; the heels are left as a vertical lump of stone.  The right hand is holding the lion's right hind leg; it is unclear what the left hand was holding, possibly the animal's tail. The lion hangs down vertically with the head facing to the viewer's left, eyes carved in high relief, the tongue protruding. Its paws are placed just above the man's own feet; the paws of the animal and the fingers and toes of the man are schematised.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

Traces of black and yellow paint on the lion's body, of yellow on the ears. Traces of black eye line and eye brow, and possibly left side of moustache. The figure's hair is a flat surface, parted in the centre and falling on the back with a straight edge. The features are worn; the face oval, the eyes slightly oblique, the mouth indicating a smile with the corners turned downwards. The earlobes are particularly large. The body is schematised with wide sloping shoulders and a slim waist. The arm is sturdy and mostly separated from the body. There are no indications of musculature or bone structure on the upper body. The base of the neck is sharp-edged and emphasised by the red band. The feet are almost parallel with the left slightly advanced; between the feet the stone has not been entirely removed. The upper half of the back is fairly flat; legs and buttocks are shown in the round; the heels are left as a vertical lump of stone.  The right hand is holding the lion's right hind leg; it is unclear what the left hand was holding, possibly the animal's tail. The lion hangs down vertically with the head facing to the viewer's left, eyes carved in high relief, the tongue protruding. Its paws are placed just above the man's own feet; the paws of the animal and the fingers and toes of the man are schematised.

description.value: Grey basalt naophorous figure with a shrine containing the god Osiris, the head and upper body of the main figure now lost.   He wears a long ankle-length kilt belted at the waist, with the outline of the leg underneath the clothing clearly delineated on the sides of the figure. The left leg is shown advancing forward ahead of the right leg, while on the right side the extended outline of the clothing emerges from under the forearm and is almost the same width as the naos. His hands are placed on either side of the walls of the shrine, with the standing figure of Osiris placed inside. Osiris is identifiable through his mummified form, the feathered atef-crown, and the crook and flail implements held across his chest. The base of the naos rests upon the main statue base. On the reverse is a slim back-pillar inscribed with a column of text, the beginning and end of the inscription now lost.   There are several abrasions to the naos, with damage to the top, edges of the shrine walls, and … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Naophorous limestone figure of Padiaset, shown kneeling before a naos with a figure of Osiris.

The figure wears a smooth ‘bag wig’ which reaches to the shoulders and is tucked behind the ears. His eyes are small and almond shaped, with a faint ridge above conveying the eyebrows. His nose is extremely broad, and his mouth is small with thick lips. The face is fleshy and rounded at the mouth, jawline and neck. A deep ‘v’ shape across the collarbone area possibly indicates the edges of his clothing, though there are no further indications of his garment at the waist or legs. His hands are placed around the sides of the naos which is held out before him, and his knees are also placed on either side of the naos. The naos is broad in size, and inside is the standing figure of the god Osiris. He is identifiable via the atef-crown, his mummiform figure, and the crook and flail implements held across his chest. His facial features are faint, but the outline of his eyes and false beard… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Limestone seated figure of Senebef, depicted cross-legged on top of a slim rectangular base.

He wears a shoulder-length striated wig with flaring ends, and the hair tucked behind oversized ears. Well-preserved traces of a red-brown paint are visible across the wig. The eyes are extremely wide and almond shaped, with a large lower eyelid and deep arched ridge conveying the eyebrows. The nose is long and slim and he has thin lips, with the edge of the lower lip sharply incised. The face is particularly rounded at the jawline. The upper body is bare, and a thick garment is tied with two knots at the breastbone and extends over the legs. An incised ridge along the clothing is visible from the left side extending down the torso and onto the legs. There is a clear bulge at the stomach area yet on the reverse there is a sharp narrowing of the waist. Both arms are placed on the thighs, with the palms facing upwards. Across the clothing on the legs are four horizontal lines of incised … (See Merlin record for full description)

He wears a shoulder-length striated wig with flaring ends, and the hair tucked behind oversized ears. Well-preserved traces of a red-brown paint are visible across the wig. The eyes are extremely wide and almond shaped, with a large lower eyelid and deep arched ridge conveying the eyebrows. The nose is long and slim and he has thin lips, with the edge of the lower lip sharply incised. The face is particularly rounded at the jawline. The upper body is bare, and a thick garment is tied with two knots at the breastbone and extends over the legs. An incised ridge along the clothing is visible from the left side extending down the torso and onto the legs. There is a clear bulge at the stomach area yet on the reverse there is a sharp narrowing of the waist. Both arms are placed on the thighs, with the palms facing upwards. Across the clothing on the legs are four horizontal lines of incised … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Black granite figure of a male official, seated in a cross-legged position.

He wears a smooth shoulder-length wig tucked behind his oversized ears. His eyes are large with thick incised lids and a thin line above conveying the arched eyebrows. His nose is broad at the nostrils, and his lips are thick with a sharply incised lower lip. The jawline is rounded and there is little definition of the neck area. The upper body is bare, with a long garment tied at the breastbone that envelops the legs. A line indicating the hem reaches from the knot of material on his left side to the right side knee. There is a clear bulge around the stomach area. His arms are placed flat against his thighs, and in between his palms are several rows of crudely carved text which extend down onto the top of the base.

There are a few chips to the wig and upper body, and the base is particularly worn and damaged on both sides and on the reverse. The figure is now attached to a modern rectangula… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Steatite group of a standing male and female figure sharing a large back-plinth.

The male figure on the left wears a shoulder-length flaring wig which is tucked behind oversized ears. His facial features are large and the lower half of his face particularly rounded and fleshy, with little indication of the neck. His eyes are wide and the nose is broad with a flattened appearance. The lips are particularly thick and sharply incised, with the outer corners of the mouth left flat. The upper body is bare, and a long garment reaching to the lower legs is tied at the chest with two visible knots of material looped at the chest. The arms are held by the side of the body and are extremely elongated. There is a slight bulge at the stomach underneath the clothing. The feet are bare and slim in size compared to the rest of the body.

The female figure on the right wears a long smooth wig reaching to the chest with faint incised lines at the ends of the hair, possibly indicating … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Serpentine figure of a male official seated on a low-backed chair.  The figure is depicted in a seated position and wears a long ankle-length garment which is tied at the waist with a visible knot of material looped at the centre of the torso. The edge of the clothing is conveyed in a vertical line running down the centre of the material. He also wears a smooth shoulder-length wig which sits high on the forehead and is tucked behind the oversized ears. The elongated arms are held at either side of the body with the palms placed flat against the legs, and the feet are placed close together. The upper body is bare, and there is a slight swelling of the chest and a clear narrowing of the waist. The eyes are wide and slope downwards at the outer corners, with a heavy ridge conveying the upper eyelid and a thin arched line for the eyebrows. The nose is almost as wide as the mouth, with thick lips and the lower lip sharply incised. The face is particularly rounded at the jawline and the chin… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Fragment of a limestone seated figure of the official Tetiky.

He wears a double-wig with long tresses of hair across the upper part of the wig and an undersection of tighter curls. His upper body appears bare, with part of a kilt belted at the waist intact between his right arm and the back of the seat. The surviving upper body shows a clear bulge around the torso area. The god's name Amun has been carved on his upper right arm. The right side of the dorsal pillar features a single column of incised text, and on the reverse of the pillar are partial remains of four columns of text. The first and second line are preserved to roughly halfway down the column while only the initial signs of the third line are visible, and the final line is completely damaged and no longer legible.

There are several chips to the stone surface, and there are gouges to Tetiky's upper body and right arm. The top of the dorsal pillar is heavily chipped at the left side.

description.value: Terracotta figure of a standing woman.  The figure of a woman dancing. She faces more or less to front, with her feet almost together, and has a huge coiffeur, brushed back from her face and forehead; it probably had a large flat bun at the back of the head, but the surface of the entire rear is flaked and abraded. She wears ball earrings, both pierced from the front. Her arms are cut off just below the shoulders, and were finished by separately made limbs attached by plaster. Our figure wears a short tunic with sleeves over a long chiton; the hanging end of a decorated belt emerges from below the tunic. The rolled tops of short boots are visible below the hem of the chiton; or they may be anklets: both feet are broken and restored in plaster and it is not possible to say whether she has bare feet or was shod. She wears a body-chain with a prominent bossed ornament.   Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt; a few traces of a white dressing survive.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Plaster head of a male figure.

He wears a tight-fitting skullcap crown with a uraeus cobra at the forehead. The body of the uraeus is thick and wide, though its head and sun-disc crown is now lost. The surface of the head is flaking and powdery, and many of the original facial features are now worn and lost. The outline of the eyes and nose are barely visible, but the mouth is mostly faded. The jawline appears fleshy and rounded. At the reverse there is no indication of a back-pillar.

There are some small abrasions to the uneven surface, and the head is now supported on a small modern base.

description.value: Granite block statue of a male official as a scribe.  He adopts a squatting position on an uneven pedestal, with the lower legs folded underneath the body. He wears a shoulder-length flared wig tucked behind the ears. His eyes are narrow and almond shaped, with arched eyebrows and a broad nose, while the mouth is small with thick lips. He wears a long garment with a large knot of material tied at the centre of his chest, and across the clothing is a column of inscribed text which extends onto the front of the statue base. His palms are placed flat against his lap, framing the inscription.  A visible break is notable across the mid-section of the figure, and has been repaired in modern times. There is also some discolouration across the stone surface, particularly on the reverse and at the figure’s face and chest.

description.value: Granite block statue of a male official as a scribe.  He adopts a squatting position on an uneven pedestal, with the lower legs folded underneath the body. He wears a shoulder-length flared wig tucked behind the ears. His eyes are narrow and almond shaped, with arched eyebrows and a broad nose, while the mouth is small with thick lips. He wears a long garment with a large knot of material tied at the centre of his chest, and across the clothing is a column of inscribed text which extends onto the front of the statue base. His palms are placed flat against his lap, framing the inscription.  A visible break is notable across the mid-section of the figure, and has been repaired in modern times. There is also some discolouration across the stone surface, particularly on the reverse and at the figure’s face and chest.

description.value: Quartzite kneeling figure of a male official on a slim square shaped base.   The figure is depicted in an asymmetrical kneeling position on a slim and narrow base. The right leg is drawn up with the foot placed flat on the top of the base, while the left leg is crossed and the left foot is tucked underneath the body. The figure wears a short knee-length kilt, and a thick line across the top of the kilt on the reverse of the figure may indicate a belt. The upper body is bare, and both hands are placed on the knees. The figure appears to hold rolls of papyrus in each hand, with slim vertical lines across the papyrus likely intended to convey text. The modelling of the hands and feet are quite crude, while added details such as the heavy chest and notable ridge indicating the spine on his back conveying the broadness of the figure. He also wears a smooth shoulder-length wig with sharply pointed edges that reach down to the neck, set high on the forehead and tucked behind the large ears. T… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Limestone stelophorous figure of Nebamun.

His plaster head has been restored in modern times to join to the current break at the neck. He wears a shoulder-length striated wig based on the surviving edges of the ancient wig worn by Nebamun, and this has been painted black. His facial features and the skin colour of his face are modern renderings. His upper body is bare with clear traces of red-brown paint conveying his skin, and he is shown kneeling and resting on his heels. His clothing is not clearly delineated though a thin line on his left ankle suggests that he wears a long kilt belted at the waist. The lower half of his body also appears to have been painted white, though this is now faded. His arms extend out to hold a small rounded stela that rests on his knees. The stela is inscribed with four slim columns of text, with the signs painted in a clear blue colour. A single horizontal line of text continues on the front of the statue base On the reverse is a broad back-pil… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Steatite group of Antef and his wife Mersebes, both shown standing on a slim rectangular base.   Mersebes stands on the right stand and wears a smooth Hathor wig tucked behind her oversized ears. Her eyes are slanted and she has arched eyebrows, a slim nose, and a small mouth. The face is particularly rounded and fleshy at the jawline, and the neck is broad. She wears a tight-fitting sheath dress that reaches to the ankles, with the abdomen and pubic area denoted with faint incisions. Her arms are extremely elongated, and held by the sides of the body. At her right side, crudely carved text is visible beside the feet on top of the statue base. Antef stands on the left and wears a flared shoulder-length wig. His ears are also oversized, and his facial features mirror those of his wife. He wears a long garment which is knotted at the waist while the upper body is bare and a slight swelling of the chest is visible. The arms, also elongated, are held by the sides of the body with the broad… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Steatite group of Antef and his wife Mersebes, both shown standing on a slim rectangular base.   Mersebes stands on the right stand and wears a smooth Hathor wig tucked behind her oversized ears. Her eyes are slanted and she has arched eyebrows, a slim nose, and a small mouth. The face is particularly rounded and fleshy at the jawline, and the neck is broad. She wears a tight-fitting sheath dress that reaches to the ankles, with the abdomen and pubic area denoted with faint incisions. Her arms are extremely elongated, and held by the sides of the body. At her right side, crudely carved text is visible beside the feet on top of the statue base. Antef stands on the left and wears a flared shoulder-length wig. His ears are also oversized, and his facial features mirror those of his wife. description.value:
Fragment of a granite block figure with figures of deities depicted across all surviving sides.

The figure’s head is now lost, and along the top of the block form his arms are folded with the hands exposed. Across the front of the block form three standing deities are depicted in raised relief, with the god Ptah at the proper left side shown in mummified form. In the centre is the god Re-Horakhty wearing the sun-disc crown, and on the proper right side is the god Amun. Each of the gods hold a was sceptre. Across both sides of the block form are further depictions of other deities in sunken relief; the goddesses Bastet and Mut are shown on the left side, accompanied by a brief label of incised text at their heads. Below them is a slim horizontal line of incised text, only a few signs now intact. On the proper right side of the block form the gods Osiris and Horus are depicted, again with an accompanying label and a similar line of incised text underneath their feet which is now… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Sandstone stelophorous male figure named Userhat, standing before a slim tall stela.

He wears a shoulder-length striated wig with faint traces of black paint. His facial features are worn, yet the outline of his rounded eyes, arched eyebrows and short nose are still discernible. Small traces of red-brown paint are also visible across the face and neck, and small sections of black paint on his left side suggest that he also had cosmetic lines at the outer corners of his eyes. He supports the tall stela in front of him with two hands, and he wears a long kilt detailed with worn white paint. His left leg advances forward slightly ahead of his right leg, and clearer traces of red-brown paint are visible across his lower legs and feet. The stela has eleven rows of short incised text, topped with a lunette featuring a pair of wedjat-eyes. The text has clear traces of blue and yellow paint within the hieroglyph signs, and red paint has been used for the border. A further horizontal … (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © Egyptian Museum, Cairo

description.value: Limestone head fragment of a female figure. The face is long with round cheeks, bulging eyes and a pointed chin. The  large eyes are protruding and pointed at the outer edges. The slim  mouth is smiling; the ears are large with the right one set higher,  making the face look asymmetrical. The head cloth is separated from  the forehead by means of a small step. At the left edge of the neck a  necklace is visible; the back of the head is flat.  Cut off at neck, chipped in various places  (nose). No visible traces of paint.

description.value: Stelophorous limestone figure of Nebiri.  (Scan from HTBM Part 8: Plate XXXI)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Stelophorous limestone figure of Nebiri: the deceased is represented kneeling on a pedestal and holding before him a stela. He wears a long wig and a long skirt reaching to the ankles. The inscription is incised in ten horizontal lines, beginning on the stela and continuing on the skirt above the knees. Apart from minor abrasions, both stela and statuette are well preserved.

He wears a long wig and a long skirt reaching to the ankles. The inscription is incised in ten horizontal lines, beginning on the stela and continuing on the skirt above the knees. Apart from minor abrasions, both stela and statuette are well preserved.

description.value: Lower part of limestone female figure, standing, wearing a simple long dress. Only the lower part of the body from knees down and the plinth are preserved. The smooth skirt falls almost vertically to the ground. Below the curved border of the lower hemline the naked feet stand on an oblique plinth which is as wide as the skirt. The feet are worked less carefully with the toes indicated only by means of grooves in the rectangular foot. The back is rounded giving the figure a lentoid cross-section.

legal.credit_line: © Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology, UCL. Photography by British Museum staff

description.value: Head from painted limestone statuette of male figure wearing a Greek helmet with a prone person (vanquished foe?) as a crest. The arms of a person(?) on the front of the helmet (painted reg, their legs (painted yellow) hang down the back and neck of the head. The prone figure had rather wide, efeminate hips (female?). The body is missing from crest. Both ears and the neck are painted red and traces on the lips. Black details include eyes, pupils and brows as if khol was used.. Only preserved on right eye. The left is chipped and worn.  A black line runs from uupper lip (moustash?) and back to neck. Another black line runs under the chin line a thin beard. Point of chin is chipped, but blsack pain covers this damage as if it has been touched up.post damage.

description.value: Fragmentary theophorous figure made from grey basalt(?), depicting a male official holding an image of the funerary god Osiris.  The figure wears a calf length kilt belted at the waist, with the left leg extending outwards. Both hands are stretched out in front to support the smaller figure of the funerary god Osiris, who is identifiable via the mummified form of the body, the feathered atef-crown, and the crook and flail items held across the chest. A single column of hieroglyphic text is inscribed on the broad back-pillar with both the beginning and the conclusion of the inscription now missing. On the left side of the back pillar and behind the figure’s body are two short inscriptions in Latin and Greek both translating to 'priest carrying Osiris', which have been carved into the stone at an unclear later date.   The upper body, feet, and base of this figure are now lost, with much of the stone surface rounded and worn. There are notable chips on the reverse of the figure towards th… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Painted limestone figure of the User, seated on a small backless chair.

The figure wears a close-cropped wig, set low on the forehead and partially covering the ears. A faded yellow paint is visible across the top of the wig. His head is slightly asymmetrical, with one ear higher than the other and the head tilted slightly towards the left side. A thin line of black paint is also visible behind the left ear and in front of the right ear. His eyes are narrow with a thick line of black paint and a short cosmetic line at the outer corners. His eyebrows are also delineated in black paint. His nose is short and narrow, with a large gap between the nose and mouth. His lips are thick and pursed together, with a sharply incised lower lip. A black line across his jawline indicates a slim beard. The neck and shoulders are broad while the arms are disproportionally thin and elongated. He also has a hunched upper back. Red-brown paint has been used across the face, upper body and legs to … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone male figure with a shaven head(chipped) and kilt; Hieroglyphic text on the belt and back-pillar; rectangular plinth.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Limestone striding figure of the male official Hor, standing on a tall rectangular base.

The figure has a large shaven head, with the right side of the skull, ear, and face, reconstructed in modern times. His eyes are narrow and slanted with a thin incised line at the upper eyelid, and his eyebrows are conveyed as long, subtle ridges which converge at the bridge of the nose. His nose is broad at the nostrils, and his mouth is small with pursed lips and a clear cupid’s bow above his upper lip. A slight smile is suggested by the gentle upturning of the corners of his mouth. The face appears fleshy and rounded at the mouth, jawline, and neck. The upper body is bare, with subtle indication of the musculature and a narrowed waist. His arms are held by the sides of the body and he holds two unidentified objects in his clenched fists, likely pieces of folded cloth. He wears a short shendyt kilt with a thick belt inscribed with a horizontal line of text. His left leg advances ahead of… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Black basalt statue of the male official Seru, depicted cross-legged on top of a rectangular base.  The figure wears a long cloak which envelops the left arm and both legs. The decorative trim on the edge of the clothing extends from the left shoulder across the chest, and on the right side from the armpit and across the waist. The right arm is placed along the right leg with the palm flat against the thigh, while the left arm is bent at the elbow with the hand placed at the centre of the chest. The figure wears a shoulder-length striated wig, set low on the forehead and tucked behind the oversized ears. The face is rounded and fleshy, with narrowed eyes and a heavy upper eyelid, a long nose, and a sharply incised mouth. The outer corners of the mouth are slightly downturned, conveying a more serious expression. The chin is raised and suggests an upward gaze. A continuous line of text is inscribed along the edges of the figure’s base, beginning at the left side and concluding on the ri… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Protome of a woman in Archaic Greek style. Terracotta figure  of woman's bust with arms, her hands concealing breasts. White coating preserved on some areas with traces of red paint on clothes. Pale red-brown fabric with grey core. Abundant fine silver an

legal.credit_line: © Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. Photography by British Museum staff

description.value: Terracotta mould-made protome of a woman. Bust of woman with hands in front of breasts with thumbs pointing up. Subtle drapery of clothes is visible covering all except wrists and hands. Terracotta figure fragment of large figure. Side and back  fragment. Mould made with an open flat back and base. White coating preserved in only small patches. Pale red-brown fabric with grey core. Abundant fine silver and gold mica, quartz and white inclusions. Section of the head and the front is still missing when reconstructed with joining parts.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Head of a limestone male figure, roughly broken at the neck.

He wears a heavy wig with detailed individual tresses of hair, including tighter curls of hair above the forehead and along the edges of the wig. There are surviving traces of black paint particularly at the lower left and right side of the wig. Red-brown paint has been applied to his face and neck to indicate his skin. His eyebrows are thick and arched, sloping down towards the temple. His eyes have a thick cosmetic line emerging from the outer corners, and the nose is short and broad at the tip. His mouth is small and his lips are pursed together, and the outer corners of the mouth are flat. His jawline is particularly rounded and fleshy.

There are small chips at the tip of the nose and lower left side of the face. The object is now attached to a small modern base.

description.value:
Limestone stelophorous figure of Qenamun, shown kneeling with a slim stela placed on top of his knees.

He wears a shoulder-length striated wig with small traces of dark paint visible across the surface. His eyes are almond shaped with black paint visible particularly in the lower eyelids, and his eyebrows are indicated by a faint arched ridge. His nose is long and broad at the tip, with a clear cupid’s bow above the upper lip. His lips are pursed together and the lower lip is sharply incised. His face is particularly rounded at the jawline and neck. His upper body is bare, and he wears a long kilt belted at the waist. A stela is supported across his legs and his arms are raised out in front of him with the palms held outwards, framing the initial two lines of the stela inscription. The stela has eight rows of incised text, with the signs clearly delineated with blue paint and each row marked with horizontal lines painted in red. The final line merges into Qenamun’s clothing, a… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Head of a limestone female figure wearing a lappet-wig and modius; painted detail on plastered linen(worn).

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary limestone head of a female figure, a partial layer of linen and plaster visible over the head.

She wears a heavy lappet-wig, its ends now broken off. Traces of black paint form a striated pattern, and traces of yellow paint are visible along the wig and also used for the face and neck. On top of the head is a short modius crown with visible red traces of paint and a small circular hole on top, likely used to attach another part of a crown or headdress. The eyes are extremely oversized and low set, and faint traces of the eyebrows show an arched outline that slopes down towards the temple. The nose is small and slim, while the mouth is also small and the thin lips are faintly incised. On either side there is a small circular hole and smoothed area. There are notable traces of linen underneath the layer of plaster across the top of the head and along the wig and crown on the left side, and onto the face along the left side of the nose and brow.

The edges o… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Quartzite figure of a male scribe sitting cross-legged on a slim asymmetrical base.   The figure is depicted in a squatting position with the legs crossed and the feet visible beneath the legs. He wears a short close-cropped wig and a short kilt belted at the waist with a pleated pattern visible along the sides and reverse, while the upper body is bare. The heavy breasts are accentuated and shown slightly sagging, while the neck is short and broad. Above the legs a thick roll of uninscribed papyrus is stretched out across the lap and held at either end in both hands. The figure’s eyes are asymmetrical and extremely wide, with heavy upper and lower eyelids and thick eyebrows. The nose is broad and bulbous at the tip, while the mouth is full with thick lips with the outer corners notably downturned. The face appears rounded particularly at the jawline. On the reverse the spine of the figure has been accentuated across the back. There does not appear to be any traces of an inscription acr… (See Merlin record for full description)

The heavy breasts are accentuated and shown slightly sagging, while the neck is short and broad. Above the legs a thick roll of uninscribed papyrus is stretched out across the lap and held at either end in both hands. The figure’s eyes are asymmetrical and extremely wide, with heavy upper and lower eyelids and thick eyebrows. The nose is broad and bulbous at the tip, while the mouth is full with thick lips with the outer corners notably downturned. The face appears rounded particularly at the jawline. On the reverse the spine of the figure has been accentuated across the back. There does not appear to be any traces of an inscription acr… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Granite block statue of the male official Wahibrehu on a slim rectangular base.  The figure is depicted in block form with the body completely enveloped in a cloak and his hands are depicted free from the clothing at the top of the block form. In his hand on the left side he holds a lotus flower. The figure wears a smooth shoulder-length wig, set low on the forehead and partly obscuring the ears. His chin merges with the stone at the top of the block. The eyes are almond shaped with faint thin eyebrows, a broad nose, and thick lips with the outer corners of the mouth slightly upturned to suggest a small smile. The statue is inscribed with five horizontal lines of text across each side of the block form which extend onto the back of the figure’s body, and an additional column of text is inscribed on the slim back-pillar. All of the inscription is left undefined by a border.   The statue is in good condition, with minimal damage. Some discolouration to the stone is notable at the left si… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Granite block statue of the male official Wahibrehu on a slim rectangular base.  The figure is depicted in block form with the body completely enveloped in a cloak and his hands are depicted free from the clothing at the top of the block form. In his hand on the left side he holds a lotus flower. The figure wears a smooth shoulder-length wig, set low on the forehead and partly obscuring the ears. His chin merges with the stone at the top of the block. description.value: COMPASS Title: Limestone statuette of a priest holding an offering table

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone figure of a kneeling priest: a juvenile type of face is combined with the fullness of body found on royal images made late in Amenhotep III's reign. The result is a sloe-eyed little figure who looks like nothing so much as a chubby, pretty child. He is, of course, a man and probably an important one. In addition to the leopard skin vestment of a priest, he wears a short wig from which hangs a braided, curled sidelock. This headdress was worn by several different kinds of priest, from funerary priests to the High Priest of Ptah at Memphis, at this time probably the second most powerful religious office in the land (after the High Priest of Amun at Thebes) and the most prestigious. Amenhotep III's crowned prince served as High Priest of Ptah, and so, later on, did the crown prince of Ramses the Great. It is probable that the priest's name and titles were inscribed on the front of the object he held, which has been entirely sheared away, along with his hands. What remains is only the negative space connecting his arms and his body to the object. From the shape of the break, however, it appears to have been an offering table on a stand. Kneeling reverently, the figure was presenting offerings to a god. The fortuitous preservation of the paint, especially on the head and back, shows that this was applied lavishly and with care, from the unusually naturalistic rendering of the leopard's pelt, including the white strip of belly fur visible along his proper left side, to the use of expensive blue pigment on his sidelock and perhaps elsewhere. Of his jewellery a "Gold of Honor" necklace of disk beads, armlets, and bracelets - only ghosts remain; one wonders if they might have been gilded.

description.value:
Limestone figure of a kneeling priest, originally holding an offering table.

He wears a short wig with a braided sidelock attached at his right side, representing a type of headdress which identifies him as a priestly figure. The hair has been detailed with heavy black paint, while there are clear traces of blue in the sidelock. His eyes are slim and elongated, with thick cosmetic lines detailed in black paint. His eyebrows were originally conveyed via black paint but are now particularly faded, though the outline is still visible. His nose is slim and has been damaged. The cupid's bow above his mouth is visible, and his lips are thick and pursed together with a sharply incised line around the edge of his mouth. Around his neck are traces of a 'gold of honour' necklace, the front of which is now lost. Across his upper body are markings in red paint detailing armlets. His arms are held out before him supporting an offering table, of which only a portion now remains, and below h… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Limestone stelophorous figure of Amenemheb, shown kneeling with a tall stela placed before him.

He wears a shoulder-length wig which is painted black and features an underlayer of tight curls. His eyes are wide with a thin incised line and short pointed cosmetic lines at the outer edges. There are clear traces of white paint. His eyebrows are thin and slope down towards the temple, and are painted black. His nose is slim and aquiline, and his thick lips are pursed together. His skin is conveyed by a red-brown coloured paint which has been applied to his face and body. His head is tilted slightly creating an upwards gaze. His upper body is bare and his hands extend out towards the stela in front of him, with his palms placed on the back of the stela. In between the figure and stela the majority of the stone has been left intact for support, and has been painted in white. He wears a knee-length white kilt with a thick belt at the waist, and he rests on his heels. White paint has… (See Merlin record for full description)

His skin is conveyed by a red-brown coloured paint which has been applied to his face and body. His head is tilted slightly creating an upwards gaze. His upper body is bare and his hands extend out towards the stela in front of him, with his palms placed on the back of the stela. In between the figure and stela the majority of the stone has been left intact for support, and has been painted in white. He wears a knee-length white kilt with a thick belt at the waist, and he rests on his heels. White paint has… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone seated male figure; incised Hieroglyphic text on the left side of the block-throne identifying the man as Anu; traces of painted detail.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone seated figure of the male official Anui on a small backless chair.  The figure is depicted in a seated position and wears a short kilt which is belted at the waist with a visible loop of material extending onto the centre of the torso. He also wears a shoulder-length striated wig, set high on the forehead and tucked behind the small shaped ears. The upper body is bare, with modelling of the narrowed waist and subtle folds of flesh at the ribcage. The stone between the main body and the arms has been left intact. The arms are slim and held close to the body with the forearms placed along the upper legs, and the left palm is placed flat on the knee while the right hand is clenched into a fist. Though the back of the figure is elongated he appears to lean slightly forward. There are faint traces of a red-brown paint around the neck which could indicate an added detail such as a broad-collar, and there appears to be further traces of the same colour at the belt and between the kn… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Limestone figure of a male official named Anui seated on a small backless chair.

Anui wears a shoulder-length striated wig, set high on the forehead and tucked behind his small shaped ears. His facial features are large and exaggerated, with wide eyes and a heavy incised cosmetic line. His eyebrows are thick and slope down towards the temple, while his nose is long and broad at the tip. His lips are sharply incised, and the face is extremely rounded at the jawline. His head appears slightly raised, suggesting an upward gaze. There is little suggestion of his neck, and his upper body is bare with subtle folds of flesh at the ribcage and a narrowed waist. His arms are slim, and his left palm is placed flat on the knee while the right hand is clenched into a fist. He wears a short kilt that is belted around the waist, with a visible loop of material extending onto the centre of the torso. His back is elongated, and appears to lean slightly forward. description.value: Steatite figure of Isis kneeling with an effigy of Osiris on her lap; right arm lost.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Steatite kneeling figure of Isis on a narrow oval shaped base, holding an effigy of Osiris across the lap.   The figure wears a smooth shoulder-length wig with a horizontal band across the forehead. At the centre of the head she bears the throne hieroglyph sign in three-dimensional form, which also functions as the name of the goddess Isis. There is no clear delineation of her clothing on the upper body, however she appears to wear a long skirt that envelops the knees and lower legs. The figure has a fleshy face and almond shaped eyes which have heavy ridges delineating the upper eyelids and elongated cosmetic lines, and long arched eyebrows which slope downwards towards the temples. Her mouth is small, and the lips appear to be curved slightly upwards. The right arm is placed against the lap, with an upturned palm that holds an effigy of the funerary god Osiris, placed horizontally across the figure’s knees. Osiris is identifiable via the mummified form of his body, and the crook and … (See Merlin record for full description)

The right arm is placed against the lap, with an upturned palm that holds an effigy of the funerary god Osiris, placed horizontally across the figure’s knees. description.value: Grey breccia female figure; back pillar.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Grey breccia female figure, depicted on a slim rectangular base.

She wears a smooth lappet-wig which is tucked behind the ears and reaches down to the chest. Her eyes are large and faintly modelled, while the nose is broad and the mouth is small in size with thick lips shown pursed together. The outer corners of the mouth have deep impressions in the stone, and they appear upturned to suggest a small smile. Her face is wide and the jawline is particularly rounded with little suggestion of the neck. She wears a long tight-fitting sheath dress and stands with the left leg advanced slightly ahead of the right leg. Both arms are held by her sides with the palms placed flat against the thigh. On the reverse is a short back-pillar that extends to the back of the figure and is inscribed with a vertical line of incised text. A line of carved text is also visible around the statue base, and there is also a brief section of inscription across the left side of the back-pillar behind the … (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Limestone seated figure of the male official Nebmose with a small standing child at his right side.

Nebmose wears a shoulder-length cropped wig and holds a lotus flower across his chest. His left arm appears to be enveloped in material, though the neckline of his clothing is not clearly delineated. His right hand is placed flat across his lap. The left side of his head is damaged, but the remains of an arched eyebrow and narrow, heavily lidded eye are visible on his right side. The tip of his nose appears broad, and his lips are thick and sharply incised. He wears a long kilt that extends to his ankles, with visible traces of white paint across the clothing. A figure representing his son stands at the right side of the seat, and is depicted nude with his finger placed upon his mouth, indicating his youth. Traces of red-brown paint used to depict their skin are visible across the bodies of both figures. His facial features appear similar to Nebmose. On the reverse, two columns … (See Merlin record for full description)

The tip of his nose appears broad, and his lips are thick and sharply incised. He wears a long kilt that extends to his ankles, with visible traces of white paint across the clothing. A figure representing his son stands at the right side of the seat, and is depicted nude with his finger placed upon his mouth, indicating his youth. Traces of red-brown paint used to depict their skin are visible across the bodies of both figures. His facial features appear similar to Nebmose. description.value: Female figure, standing with left foot advanced and both arms outstretched from the elbows. The right hand is clenched, the fingers bent around a void into which an object, now lost, originally fitted. The left hand is open, with the palm uppermost and a metal pin, projecting upwards, which originally held in place some object now lost. The female wears a short hairstyle or wig, which fits closely around the head and frames the face. It conceals the ears, and ends at the level of the chin. It consists of rows of short curls, with chiselled detail representing the individual hairs of which the curls were formed. A gilded collar covers the shoulders and ends above the breasts. The outer row of this collar consisted of ‘drop’ beads and it is likely that the other rows were also represented in detail but the present condition of this area prevents clear identification. The figure wears a tightly-fitting dress which extends to above the ankles and reveals the bodily form beneath. It has wid… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary quartzite figure of the king Akhenaten, only the upper torso remaining.

The king wears a thin, tight-fitting pleated garment. The neckline is not clearly discernible however the rippled texture of the material is conveyed across the left upper arm, shoulder, and across the back. The pleated pattern is also conveyed in tighter raised ridges of material across the stomach and breasts. There is a clear indication of his collarbone and breasts underneath the clothing, and a narrowing of his waist. His right arm extends across the torso and in his right hand, now lost, the king held a crook implement that extends towards his right shoulder. There are several pairs of cartouches inscribed across the body, the most noticeable include two at the torso and two fragmentary cartouches on the left upper arm. Fainter cartouches are found across the chest on both the left and right side and on the right forearm. On the reverse, possible traces of a slim back-pillar remains, thou… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Kneeling limestone figure of a male official holding an offering table.

He wears a smooth shoulder-length wig that partially covers his ears and is painted black. His eyes are wide with short pointed cosmetic lines, and thin eyebrows conveyed by a painted black line. His nose is broad and his thick lips are pursed together with slightly upturned corners. His skin is delineated with red-brown paint, and his eyes are detailed with black and white paint. His upper body appears to have been painted entirely in the same red-brown colour as his face, before a separate layer of white paint was applied to convey a short-sleeved tunic with a v-neck shape. Patches of the paint have begun to break away across the chest, revealing the layers of colour. The body itself has still been modelled with evidence of a narrowed waist and subtle folds of flesh at the stomach. He wears a long white kilt that covers his legs and he adopts a kneeling position resting on his heels. He supports a slim o… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value:
Serpentine female figure standing on a slim rectangular base.

The figure wears a smooth Hathor wig with curled ends of the hair reaching to the chest, and a separate broad section of hair at the back. The wig is tucked behind her extremely oversized ears. She has a small rounded face with large eyes and a heavy upper eyelid. The nose and mouth are slim, and there is little definition of the neck area from the upper body. She wears a tight-fitting sheath dress with edges of material delineated across the breasts and waist. Her elongated arms are held by the sides of the body. Her waist is extremely narrow while her hips and legs are broad, and her feet are placed close together. On the reverse is a broad back-pillar which appears to be uninscribed.

A modern paper label on the lower section of the back-pillar identifies the item as being from Karnak. There are small chips and scratches around the base, feet, and on both sides of the back-pillar.

description.value:
Limestone figure of Harpocrates, damage to the reverse of the body and the lower legs and feet now lost.

Harpocrates wears the distinctive sidelock of hair, with no clear delineation of the hairline across the forehead or sides of the face. A raised area of stone at the centre of the forehead would have once contained the image of a uraeus cobra. The god wears a heart amulet suspended low across his chest, and the outline of a thin belt across the waist suggests that he wears a long kilt, the legs and pubic area still visible through the clothing. The fragment of his upper legs suggest that his left leg advances forward ahead of the right leg, adopting the conventional striding pose. The right arm is held by the side of the body. His wide eyes are delineated with wide ridges, and his eyebrows are low set and highly arched. The nose is broad at the tip and the mouth is pursed with thick lips. The face is fleshy and rounded particularly around the jawline.

The left arm… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone head of a male figure, possible the Egyptian god Nefertem.Traces of sintering on the entire surface. The nose is missing. The face is slim with a long forehead and very large eyes which stretch to the temples. The right eye is almond-shaped while the lower lid of the left is straight and the upper extremely arched. The mouth was probably small and closed with a light smile. In the centre of the chin a slim baulk is visible which reaches down to the neck. The long, slim ears are set high. The hair is worked as an even mass which is placed on the head in a flat manner but billows out towards the lower edge. Remarkable is the mass of hair which is pulled forward and is huddled against the lower edge of the cheeks right below the ears. Seen in profile the head thins towards the top.

description.value: Head,torso and thighs of light grey limestone male figure, standing, with painted 'apron' (shendit). The feet, the outer part of the right arm except for the upper arm and hand, as well as the tip of the nose are missing. Traces of scratching are visible on the entire surface. Weathering particularly obvious on the face. The area below the right knee is chipped off; break above the left ear, light break at the collarbone. Traces of paint: Black pigment is visible on the moustache, hair, eyebrows, the eye outline with iris (right eye), and the kneecap as well as an armband on the left arm. Red paint is visible on the mouth, apron, belt (the end of which is only painted tucked in behind the rest of the belt to the right) and hairband (right temple); the ears are reddish-brown. The apron was highly decorated, with verticle stripes represented and scored grooves. A band at the bottom of the apron may have been in yellow, now faded. Spoiled black colour on the back below the hair, below the belt on the left hip and left leg with part of an in-between rod, as well as above the right buttock down to the right foot.

legal.credit_line: Photograph © Museum of Fine Arts, Boston

description.value: Upper part (without head) of limestone female figure, carrying vessel; painted.The head and lower part below the right hand are missing. Broad painted red collar.The woman is holding a vessel in the hand of her vigurously bent left arm in front of her chest. The right hands down straight. A pearl necklace with a single row and a pendant is worn around the neck. The small breasts are set high, the body is fairly broad and chunkily worked. The right shoulder is sloping down while the left with the bent arm is almost horizontal. The garment falls down from the armpit in a lightly billowing fashion. The back is flat. The inscription is on the right side and incised turned 90 degrees.The figure is inscribed with a dedication to Aphrodite.(Limestone figure, flat on the back, the lines of the carving at the front simple and distinct, broken off at the knees, the head gone. The right arm extended full length at the side, the left bent across the breast, the hand holding a cup. Portion of a necklace. Vestiges of red colour around the neck.inscribed dedication of POLYERMOS MAN .. TE APHRODITEI. [description in MfA Stone ledger])dimensions: 10.3 x 6.7 cm.

legal.credit_line: Photograph © Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. Photographer François Leclère, The British Museum

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary black granite figure of the male official Surer.

What survives of the lower torso section suggests subtle modelling of the musculature of the abdomen, and a narrowing at the waist. The torso appears bare, and his arms are placed flat against his lap. He wears a long ankle-length kilt with a pleated front panel, with a long single column of text incised down the centre of the garment. His feet and the front of the base are lost but have been restored in modern times. On both sides of the seat are five columns of incised text, with the left side addressed to the god Amun and the right addressed to the god Atum. On the reverse the back-pillar is inscribed with two columns of text, the upper portion of both lines now missing.

The upper portion of the figure is missing, with an uneven break across the body and back of the seat. His torso, hands and the edges of the seat are also chipped. The object has been attached to a tall modern rectangular base.

description.value: Terracotta figure of a pregnant woman seated on a birth-stool.  A woman seated on a birthing-stool. She leans slightly back and wears a long chiton pulled up above her right knee to leave her lower leg bare and held back by a comb-like clip resting on her thigh; her left leg is draped to the ankle. The chiton is girdled just under her breasts, with a knot at the front. She has a himation, a shawl-like cloth, over her head but showing her centre-parted hair, with two ends tucked together just above the breasts. Only the stumps of her arms remain, with finished ends: the arms were made separately and attached, presumably with plaster, but their disposition cannot certainly be decided. Her belly is distended, and she sits on the stool, which has a flat face and sides, the seat projecting at the top. Unfortunately the whole rear of the figure has broken away at the join and the appearance of the back of the stool is not known. The figure as set upon a stepped plinth, but most of it is lost.  Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with areas remaining, both inside and out, of a white dressing; the stool may have been painted a light pinkish-brown; there is a small area of pink paint on the chiton near the left ankle.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

She leans slightly back and wears a long chiton pulled up above her right knee to leave her lower leg bare and held back by a comb-like clip resting on her thigh; her left leg is draped to the ankle. The chiton is girdled just under her breasts, with a knot at the front. She has a himation, a shawl-like cloth, over her head but showing her centre-parted hair, with two ends tucked together just above the breasts. Only the stumps of her arms remain, with finished ends: the arms were made separately and attached, presumably with plaster, but their disposition cannot certainly be decided. Her belly is distended, and she sits on the stool, which has a flat face and sides, the seat projecting at the top. Unfortunately the whole rear of the figure has broken away at the join and the appearance of the back of the stool is not known. The figure as set upon a stepped plinth, but most of it is lost… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Head and shoulder section of a schist figure of a king wearing the nemes; back pillar.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Fragmentary schist figure of the head and upper body of a king, much of the body and base now missing.  The king is depicted wearing the nemes headcloth with wide striped lappets which extend down past the shoulders, the tips of the cloth now lost. The material is also tucked behind the large ears, and the wide horizontal band of the nemes is set low on the forehead. Above this and the king’s forehead is the coiled body of the uraeus cobra, now headless. The shoulders appear to be bare, and what survives of the neck does not appear to suggest any jewellery worn. The eyes are narrow and slanted, with a heavy lower eyelid and sunken skin underneath the eye area. A thin line above conveys the eyebrows, which converge at the bridge of the nose. Much of the face is now damaged, but the face appears fleshy and rounded particularly around the jawline.   In addition to the damage and loss of the figure from the neck and across the upper body, the nose and mouth have also been damaged, with lar… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Light grey limestone head of a figure; painted. The forehead with the frontal area of hair, parts of the left eye and the nose chipped off. Light vertical chiselling marks are visible on the hair behind the ears. Traces of red paint on right ear, neck and right cheek as well as the left eye. Black around the right ear,both  lower lids, right eyebrow, the hair line and bewteen the hair grooves and right corner fo the mouth. The broad face tapers towards the chin. The eyes appear like added plates and are large and almond-shaped. The broad nose is set above the lightly smiling mouth with its slim lips. The large ears are left embossed. The high hair-do rises almost vertically above the forehead and is structured by means of roughly worked vertical grooves at that point. The rest of the hair is left smooth and falls onto the back. The back is flat.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Painted terracotta figure of a woman carrying an alabastron; she originally wore a hat, now missing.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Painted terracotta figure of a woman.  A woman standing, her head tilted somewhat to her right and looking slightly to her left. She wears a chiton falling in folds to her feet, and girdled below the breasts. A large himation veils her head and falls on each side, wrapped round her right arm and hand and gripped by her left hand, which is also covered in drapery; her right foot, in a pointed shoe, emerges from the hem of her chiton. Her hair is worn in the melon style, covering her ears but leaving discearrings exposed. She wore a conical, wide-brimmed hat (a tholia), but it is now lost. From her right wrist, an alabastron dangles: it is of a type common and changing little from the sixth century on, but not far into Hellenistic times, with an elongated body, rounded bottom, narrow neck and wide everted rim, with small ear-handles below the neck. The rear is largely unworked, with a small circular vent, and she stands on a low rectangular plinth, open below.   Hollow; the body was made in a two-piece mould. The head and neck were produced in a one or two-piece mould and applied to the body; the veil part of the himation was modelled and added, as was the alabastron; the plinth was also made separately and the figure luted to it. Micaceous orange-brown clay, apparently a Nile silt, with a grey core, perhaps mixed with a finer clay. Much of the overall white dressing survives, and scientific analysis shows it to be calcite. The upper and lower borders of the chiton are decorated with blue paint, and there are bands of red below the girdle and above the blue band at the bottom of the garment; the girdle is painted yellow. Her hair, mouth, earrings and shoe are painted red, and the alabastron yellow, which also has a narrow band of red paint at handle-level and red also on its mouth. There is no coloured decoration on the rear.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone kneeling figure shown holding an effigy of Osiris across the lap; representation of Bes and Harpocrates at the back; socket on top of the head for the attachment of a headdress.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone kneeling figure on a narrow oval shaped base, holding an effigy of Osiris across the lap.  The figure is shown in a kneeling position resting on the heels, and wears a smooth shoulder-length wig set high along the forehead with a circular outlet at the top of the head to originally attach to a headdress, which is now lost. The figure wears a long kilt indicated at the waist, enveloping the knees and legs. The chest is exposed, and the broad arms, breastbone and torso have been subtly modelled. The eyes are wide and almond shaped with heavy ridges indicating the upper and lower eyelids. The face is fleshy with a broad nose and thick lips, and the face is particularly rounded at the jawline. The arms of the figure are placed against the lap, with both palms turned upwards and holding an effigy of the funerary god Osiris, placed horizontally across the figure’s knees. Osiris is identifiable via the mummified form of his body, the feathered atef-crown, and the crook and flail imp… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Upper part of limestone female figure holding a bird.Porous limestone with holes. The lower part from about knee level is missing, as is the left shoulder. Part broken off the right upper arm. Continuous breaks beside the left arm and right below the chest. The face is heavily worn with numerous fissures. The curved kolpos of the almost vertically falling, slender garment is placed at approximately thigh level. The left arm hangs down straight, the right is bent. In the right hand she is holding a calmly seated bird, probably a dove, just below the small, highly set breasts. The necklace is rendered as very close to the neck. The face with its pointy chin apparently had eyes left in a more or less rudimentary state and a small mouth. The ears may have been decorated with jewellery as the thick ear lobes suggest. The hair or respectively the veil is set close to the head and is separated from the forehead by means of a fine edge and falls onto the back. The back is flat.

legal.credit_line: © Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford. Photography by British Museum staff

description.value: Limestone figure of a female worshipper carrying a bird for sacrifice/dedication. She is wearing a veil  which is lifted almost diadem-like above and separated from the forehead by means of a fine edge and falls behind the ears and onto the back. She wears a long chiton with curved kolpos and a necklace with a central medallion very close to the neck. The curved kolpos of the almost vertically falling, slender garment is placed at approximately thigh level. The face with its pointy chin apparently had large slightly protruding rudimentary eyes with high brows and a small smiling mouth. The very large, flatly worked ears may have been decorated with jewellery as the thick ear lobes suggest. She is standing, with a calmly seated bird, probably a dove, sitting gently on her right hand crossed just below her small, highly set breasts. Her left arm hangs by her side. The back is flat and roughly rendered. Possivbly faint traces of red paint on chiton. Upper body fragment, missing lower legs… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary steatite male figure, the lower legs and base now missing.

The figure wears a short smooth cropped wig which is set high on the forehead and covers the ears. His eyes are large, wide-set and with a thin incised line at the upper eyelid. A faint ridge above indicates the slightly arched eyebrows. His nose is extremely broad, and his mouth is wide with thick lips. The lower lip is sharply incised. His face is particularly rounded at the cheeks and jawline, with a slight bulging area of flesh around the broad neck. Both arms are held by the sides of the body, with a large section of the right arm now lost. Both fists are clenched. The upper body is bare, with a visible ridge across the chest indicating the musculature and a narrowed waist. There is a slight swelling of the lower belly. He wears a shendyt kilt belted at the waist, and his left leg advances forward ahead of the right leg. On the reverse is a slim back-pillar inscribed with a single column of text, the t… (See Merlin record for full description)

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Limestone figure of a female likely representing a goddess or queen, seated on a high backed chair.  The figure is depicted with a closely cropped wig of curled hair, set high on the forehead and with visible traces of blue paint across the left side, reverse, and right side. There is no clear suggestion of a royal headdress or crown as any original decoration to the top of the head has mostly eroded. The figure wears a long garment reaching to the calves, with folds of cloth and long sleeves enveloping the arms. In her left hand she holds a small ankh symbol with surviving traces of red paint, while her right hand is held against the chest. Underneath her clenched fist and at her abdomen are two holes which were likely used to hold a small separate object or possibly two objects in place, though these are now lost. The body of the figure is crudely modelled, with rounded breasts placed high on the chest and the body depicted completely flat on the reverse. Across the face and front of… (See Merlin record for full description)

Underneath her clenched fist and at her abdomen are two holes which were likely used to hold a small separate object or possibly two objects in place, though these are now lost. The body of the figure is crudely modelled, with rounded breasts placed high on the chest and the body depicted completely flat on the reverse. description.value: Limestone figure of a female likely representing a goddess or queen, seated on a high backed chair.  The figure is depicted with a closely cropped wig of curled hair, set high on the forehead and with visible traces of blue paint across the left side, reverse, and right side. There is no clear suggestion of a royal headdress or crown as any original decoration to the top of the head has mostly eroded. The figure wears a long garment reaching to the calves, with folds of cloth and long sleeves enveloping the arms. In her left hand she holds a small ankh symbol with surviving traces of red paint, while her right hand is held against the chest. Underneath her clenched fist and at her abdomen are two holes which were likely used to hold a small separate object or possibly two objects in place, though these are now lost. The body of the figure is crudely modelled, with rounded breasts placed high on the chest and the body depicted completely flat on the reverse.
