description.value:
Lower portion of a basalt kneeling figure of a male official.

He wears a short kilt across the thighs and he is shown kneeling and resting on his heels.The wide belt of the kilt is clearly visible, and his waist appears narrowed with an indication of the musculature of the abdomen across the bare upper body. There is a suggestion of flesh bulging over the top of the belt on the reverse. His hands are placed along his legs, framing an inscription across the clothing composed of two short vertical lines, both undefined by a border. Behind the figure is the lower portion of a slim back-pillar with two columns of incised text. A continuous single line of horizontal text is also inscribed around the sides of the statue base, moving from right to left.

The left side arm of the figure is damaged from the elbow to the wrist, though the outline of the forearm is still visible. There are also small chips to the knees, the right side forearm, and the right side leg. The object … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone statue of Huy: this piece consists of the remains of a kneeling figure holding a stela in front of it. On the upper part of the stela the barque of Ra is depicted in sunk relief. Below it are six horizontal lines of incised text containing a prayer to Ra on behalf of the workman Huy. Only the lower part of the statue consisting of part of the torso and legs remains. The top of the stela is heavily damaged and the lowest line of text is preserved only in part. The sides of the stela are chipped and there are gouges and scratches on the face of the stela. Traces of red paint can be seen on the body and legs of the statue.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value:
Fragmentary limestone stelophorous statue of Huy.

The upper body is now lost, but Huy is shown kneeling and resting on his heels with his arms raised out to the large stela in front of him. His upper body was bare and a red-brown paint was applied to convey his skin. This is particularly visible on the right side of his body, though fainter traces of this colour are also visible across his forearms and his feet. He wears a long kilt that may have been painted white. The upper portion of the stela is lost, but originally contained a relief scene depicting the barque of Re in sunken relief. Below this are six horizontal lines of incised text, the final line now particularly damaged.

The lower left side of the stela and statue base have been restored. There are numerous chips and gouges to the stela, particularly along its sides, and there are further small chips to the statue body. The object is supported by a thick modern base.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Upper body and head of yellow limestone male figure (kriophoros, ram-bearer); painted. Only the upper body is preserved, the face is very worn. Groove on right thigh of the ram; red on its mouth and ears. The figure is wearing a short-sleeved belted chiton whose long kolpoi hang down at the sides. The border is stepped around the neck line. The slender body of the figure is broadened towards the shoulders in a cup-shaped manner. The arms are quite slim; the left is hanging down close to the body, the right is bent with the hand grasping firmly the legs of a ram which is lying around the man's neck. The animal's head is raised over the figure's left shoulder, it is facing the front. The man's chin is pointy; the left eye which is still recognisable is slim and almond-shaped. The hair is strictly separated from the face and rendered as a flat cap leaving the slightly protruding ears uncovered. The back is entirely flat. Cypriot sculpture of a hunter, with ram (bound), carried on shoulers anmd  secured with his right hand.He is wearing a headress and has large projecting  ears. Missing legs and left hand. Back is flat an plain apart for crude outline  of horns and back of the hunters head. Both faces are featureless, badly  worn.  Upper part of flattish sandstone figure of a standing man carrying a  horned ram over his shoulder, R hand holding all ram's feet

description.value: Gypsum alabaster (calcium sulphate) kouros, painted.  Standing nude youth. Both lower legs are missing from the knee and are now  restored in plaster; the statuette is broken obliquely across the neck and across the thighs and rejoined with slight restorations, including the right forearm and parts of the front surface of the neck and of both thighs.  The figure is standing in a frontal position, balanced on both legs, the left advanced, the right drawn back. The arms hang stiffly at the sides, the fingers closed and grasping short rods after the Egyptian convention, with thumbs pointing downwards. At the back the hands are unworked. Only the upper arms are detached from the body.  A thick cord, like a diadem, is running across the forehead from ear to ear; above it, the hair is parted in the centre back to the crown and swept back behind, to fall in front of each shoulder in four straight tresses and down the back in eleven, three tresses are falling down onto the shoulders on either side. The whole of the hair is cut up by grooves into oblong patches; the vertical grooving is more regular than the horizontal.   The head is high and rounded; it is separated from the body by means of a fine incised line around the neck. The face is long and tapering, with a pointed chin. The ears are large, with swollen lobes. The eyes are large with protruding eyeballs and the lower lid almost horizontal; the outer angle is prolonged; the eyebrows are incised lines. The nose, which is partly broken away, is long and wide at the base. The mouth is small, with fairly straight lips, the upper slightly projecting and the corners indicating a smile; there are deep hollows under the corners. The cheeks are flat and fleeing towards the back; the chin is protruding.  The body is long and narrow, with sloping rounded shoulders, and very high breasts and waist. The breast shows an arrowhead pectoral groove underneath; the nipples and also the navel are indicated by incised circles. The stomach and the pubic area are protruding. The section is generally narrow; the back is a flattened plane with spinal groove and a small buttocks. The upper arms are very short; the elbows placed high and marked by an arrowhead groove; the thumbnails are indicated. The thighs are long and rather sturdy as well as slightly ridged, and they are not separated until just above the knees; the kneecap is indicated by a grooved lozenge. Neither arms not legs show muscles.  The whole was originally covered with reddish-brown paint, which remains largely on face and shoulders and in traces elsewhere. There is a touch of vermilion on the lips and hairband and black traces are remaining on the hair, around the eyes and on the left eyebrow; black shadows indicate a beard on the upper lip as well as pubic hair.

description.value:
Green serpentine standing figure of the god Min with the wings of a falcon, part of the base and right hand now missing.

On top of the head is a circular crown with a deep recess, partially damaged on the left side. This possibly contained a separately made headdress decorated with plumes, now lost. His facial features are broad and there is little definition of the neck. He has large slanted eyes which possibly originally contained inlays, and a thick upper eyelid and cosmetic line. The eyebrows are thick and slightly arched, while the nose is broad and there is a visible cupid’s bow above his upper lip. Folds of flesh are visible on either side of his nose. His lips are full and fleshy, and a short false beard is attached to his chin. His upper body is bare with limited definition, and his right arm is raised to his head. This hand is now missing, but likely held an object such as a flail. His left hand is held across the body and a deep circular recess indicates that he hel… (See Merlin record for full description)

Green serpentine standing figure of the god Min with the wings of a falcon, part of the base and right hand now missing.

On top of the head is a circular crown with a deep recess, partially damaged on the left side. This possibly contained a separately made headdress decorated with plumes, now lost. His facial features are broad and there is little definition of the neck. He has large slanted eyes which possibly originally contained inlays, and a thick upper eyelid and cosmetic line. The eyebrows are thick and slightly arched, while the nose is broad and there is a visible cupid’s bow above his upper lip. Folds of flesh are visible on either side of his nose. His lips are full and fleshy, and a short false beard is attached to his chin. His upper body is bare with limited definition, and his right arm is raised to his head. This hand is now missing, but likely held an object such as a flail. His left hand is held across the body and a deep circular recess indicates that he hel… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Basalt striding male figure on a slim rectangular base.  The figure wears a short cropped wig which is set high on the forehead and covers the ears. His eyes are rounded with a heavy upper eyelid, and the brow is indicated as a flat ridge. His nose is long and broad, and positioned close to the mouth which is small with thin, sharply incised lips. The outer corners of the mouth are upturned to suggest a slight smile. The neck is extremely broad. His upper body is bare, with faint modelling of the chest and abdomen. His arms are held by the sides of the body, and he holds a piece of folded cloth in both clenched fists. He wears a short shendyt kilt belted at the waist, with the beltline drooping slightly forward at the stomach and sitting higher on the waistline at the back. His left leg advances forward ahead of the right leg in a conventional striding position, and his legs are broad in size.  On the reverse is a slim back-pillar extending to the neck of the figure, which appears to b… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Head and upper body of alabaster male figure (kouros); painted. Both legs are missing from below pubic area, as are both arms from the mid upper arm onward and the penis. The nose is broken off, the facial surface worn. The head was broken off with a break through the neck; the areas of breakage are very worn, particularly around the hair. Residue of paint can be traced; there is black pigment visible in the incisions of the tresses falling to the front on the right side, a red shimmer below the lower lip and a black line indicating the side edges of the pubic hair. Black also outlines the pectoral muscles, outlines the eyes and just below the nose (now worn), possinly representing moustash. The figure is stocky with a sturdy neck, short torso, and drawn in small of the back. The arms were stuck to the body and were only separated for about 1 cm around the waist. Thre pectorals are strongly protruding, the buttocks is substantial. Linea Alba and spine are indicated by means of groove and incised line. The head is rather large, above the forehead there is a flat headband which is covered by three horizontally running frontal tresses around the temples and is not continued at the back. On top of the calvarium, behind the frontal tresses, ten tresses are set which are falling straight onto the back, leaving the ears visible; at the front of the hair mass, three tresses are formed on either side which fall over the shoulders from behind the ears. The tresses are rendered as an irregular broad, flat or slightly rounded ridges and are evenly cut in the back.  The face is broad and u-shaped with tight skin. The short chin merges into the sturdy neck almost without indication. The surface is very worn. The eyes are slightly oblique, rendered as fine plates, and are hardly embedded. The nose broadens towards the tip, the mouth is broad and the nasolabial folds are prominent; the ears are large and not very carefully worked.

description.value: Dark greyish brown limestone male figure, standing, wearing chiton and himation; damaged; painted.The feet are missing. Hair, eyebrows, eye outline and pupils, moustash (?)  as well as the fringe of the garment's hemline are painted black, the latter are limited by a painted red border. Red paint is visible on the right shoulder. A black line falls from the fringe of the garment. The smooth short-sleeved Chiton widens to a cone shape at the bottom, the upper hemline is swung upwards in a slight curve. He is wearing a tightly fitted himation on top of the chiton; the himation has a fringed border which runs from approximately the right knee to the left shoulder, a corner of the mantle is slung over the left shoulder and falls onto the back. The right arm is strongly bent and rests in a strap of the mantle which is pulled down from neckline to pectoral level. The right hand is rendered plastically in a fist except for the thumb; the left arm is hanging down with the hand forming a fist as well. The head is rendered fully plastically and is turned forward and slightly up. The mouth is slim and exhibits a light smile. The upper lip is crudely protruding but is without a beard as there is no evidence for paint. The eyes are very large and protruding and widely framed by the eyebrows. The hair is of medium length and falls as a merged rounded mass into the neck. It is carefully styled with fine chiselling marking a zig-zag pattern. A deep groove separates hair and forehead. The rear is flat, however, the arms, garments, hair and paint are, even if less carefully, rendered.

The smooth short-sleeved Chiton widens to a cone shape at the bottom, the upper hemline is swung upwards in a slight curve. He is wearing a tightly fitted himation on top of the chiton; the himation has a fringed border which runs from approximately the right knee to the left shoulder, a corner of the mantle is slung over the left shoulder and falls onto the back. The right arm is strongly bent and rests in a strap of the mantle which is pulled down from neckline to pectoral level. The right hand is rendered plastically in a fist except for the thumb; the left arm is hanging down with the hand forming a fist as well. The head is rendered fully plastically and is turned forward and slightly up. The mouth is slim and exhibits a light smile. The upper lip is crudely protruding but is without a beard as there is no evidence for paint. The eyes are very large and protruding and widely framed by the eyebrows. The hair is of medium length and falls as a merged rounded mass into the neck. It is carefully styled with fine chiselling marking a zig-zag pattern. A deep groove separates hair and forehead. The rear is flat, however, the arms, garments, hair and paint are, even if less carefully, rendered.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Steatite striding figure of Senebmiu on a slim rectangular base.  The figure wears a smooth cropped wig, set high on the forehead and covering the ears. His eyes are wide and rounded, with a thick upper eyelid and sunken skin underneath the eyes. Faint ridges indicate the eyebrows, which slope down towards the temple on either side of the face. His nose is broad and his mouth is wide with long, thin lips. The outer corners of the mouth are slightly upturned to suggest a small smile. The face is fleshy and rounded at the cheeks and jawline. His upper body is bare, with clear modelling of the chest, broad arms, and narrow torso.The arms are placed at the sides of the body with both fists clenched. He wears a short shendyt kilt with a thick belt, and his left leg advances forward ahead of the right leg. The belt line sits higher at the back and droops forward at the front, suggesting a slight bulge at the stomach. On the reverse is a slim back-pillar which is uninscribed. The top of the b… (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Limestone theophorous figure of Nebra: a statuette of a standing individual holding before him a figure of Osiris. The  inscription  is painted in black on the rear of the statuette. On the right shoulder of the statuette appears the name of Thoth, lord of Hermopolis painted in red. The name of [Thoth], lord of writing, is painted in red on the left shoulder, but the name of the god is no longer legible. The statuette is well preserved apart from a broken nose. The bodies of Nebra and Osiris are painted white and their faces are red with details in black apart from the pupils of the eyes which are red. The crown of Osiris is white and the wig of Nebra is black.

description.value:
Limestone theophorous figure of the male official Nebra holding a figure of the god Osiris.

Nebra wears a long striated wig and a long pleated kilt which is belted at the waist. Folds of flesh are emphasised under each pronounced breast. He has wide eyes, arched eyebrows, and a narrow mouth. The face is rounded and fleshy, particularly around the jawline. Both of his hands are placed across the shoulders of the funerary god Osiris, who is identifiable via his mummified form, the feathered atef-crown, and the crook and flail implements held across the chest. His feet are planted in between and slightly on top of Nebras own feet. Red-brown paint has been used to indicate the skin of both figures, black paint used for the wig and eyes, and white paint for the clothing of both figures, and Osiris’ crown. A brief line of inscription has been painted in black across Nebra’s back with the signs towards the lower body slightly faded. The names and titles of the god Thoth are painted … (See Merlin record for full description)

Limestone theophorous figure of the male official Nebra holding a figure of the god Osiris.

Nebra wears a long striated wig and a long pleated kilt which is belted at the waist. Folds of flesh are emphasised under each pronounced breast. He has wide eyes, arched eyebrows, and a narrow mouth. The face is rounded and fleshy, particularly around the jawline. Both of his hands are placed across the shoulders of the funerary god Osiris, who is identifiable via his mummified form, the feathered atef-crown, and the crook and flail implements held across the chest. His feet are planted in between and slightly on top of Nebras own feet. Red-brown paint has been used to indicate the skin of both figures, black paint used for the wig and eyes, and white paint for the clothing of both figures, and Osiris’ crown. A brief line of inscription has been painted in black across Nebra’s back with the signs towards the lower body slightly faded. The names and titles of the god Thoth are painted … (See Merlin record for full description)

description.value: Blue glazed composition wig from royal statue.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Blue glazed composition wig from royal statue.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Blue glazed composition wig from royal statue: ancient plaster covers the interior of the wig, revealing how it was attached to the statue's head; a hole, which seems original, is in the interior top of the wig, an expected feature for a tenon for a crown, especially since a crown was probably intended to surmount the wig. Yet the hole does not extend through to the exterior. There is, however, a small square area on the top bare of glaze on which some attachment may have been fixed, such as a horned 'atef' crown. The inlaid gilded plaster diadem with streamers, set in a channel above the brow of the wig, mimics a golden ribbon. Polychrome rectangular glass inlays are in red, to imitate cornelian, alternating with robin's egg blue, to imitate turquoise. A uraeus, symbol of royalty, originally teared up at the front. The inlaid headband and streamers were once "tied" in a bow of lotus blossoms at the back in a pattern already a thousand years old, deriving from Old Kingdom boatmen's headgear and in turn based on plant forms. The pendant streamers ended in inlaid blue glass uraei (cobras), though only that on the proper right is preserved.
